page.title: 05LOCAL HISTORY,DOWNS EDINGTON
page.content: Evidence of prehistoric man's occupation of this area is shown by the iron age field system above the slope of Longcombe Bottom. There is ancient terracing on the south side, visible from the Imber Road. Strip lynchets are to be seen south of West Down farm; they run diagonally to the road from NE to SW. It is thought that strip lynchets were created to make more land available for cultivation in the population explosion of the thirteenth century.The eighteenth century turnpiked Bath to Sarum road is now a trackway. It runs parallel to the north boundary of this block, from the old lime kiln on Coulston Hill. It then turns SE through Stoke Hill past another quarry. Two milestones still exist in this block, dated 1763.
